top_categories.workout_context: At 124 miles, The Rift punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
The Rift’s black volcanic sand, sharp lava rock demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing The Rift isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
The Rift rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Every session at The Rift intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at The Rift when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at The Rift — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of The Rift. Make this intensity feel like home.
The Rift’s black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
At 124 miles, The Rift rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at The Rift — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what The Rift’s black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: July in Hvolsvöllur, Southern Iceland — 10-15°C (50-59°F) with extreme variability. Cold + wet + wind. Hypothermia risk is real. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before The Rift — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for The Rift’s 124 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at The Rift demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: black volcanic sand, sharp lava rock, loose highland roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 124 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 124 miles of black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock in Hvolsvöllur, Southern Iceland.
